Award.AwardTitle: Infrared Chiral Plasmons for Vibrational Circular Dichroism Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jennifer Shumaker-Parry and her group at the University of Utah are working to improve capabilities for measuring the "handedness" (chirality) of molecules. Chirality arises when a molecule and its mirror image are not superimposable. Chirality is critically important in nature and medicine - for example, it is common for one molecular form of a drug to be effective while its mirror image is ineffective or even toxic. The Shumaker-Parry group is striving to enhance the utility of a chirality-sensitive method known as Vibrational Circular Dichroism (VCD) by utilizing the ability of certain metal nanostructures to selectively enhance the absorption of polarized infrared light by chiral molecules. The research incorporates elements of materials science, physics, surface chemistry, and engineering, thereby providing excellent interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students who work together on nanofabrication, materials characterization, optical studies, simulations, and calculations. Professor Shumaker-Parry and her students organize and participate in science education and outreach programs on campus and in the community to encourage students to participate in science. These hands-on nanoscience activities provide excellent opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to mentor participants and learn to communicate their research to a broad audience.

Professor Shumaker-Parry and her group are studying plasmonic nanostructures with tunable infrared (IR) plasmons and orientation-dependent chiroptical activity for plasmon-enhanced VCD spectroscopy. VCD combines IR spectroscopy and circular dichroism (CD) to provide information about chemical groups and local environment enabling chiral-based structural analysis of small molecules, biological molecules, and higher order assemblies. Nanostructures with both tunable IR plasmons and chiroptical behavior form the foundation of systematic studies of the impact of local electric and magnetic fields in VCD spectroscopy of chiral molecules. By manipulating chiroptical behavior of plasmonic nanostructures using control of structure and orientation, symmetric and asymmetric localized electric and magnetic fields are produced. The influence of these sculpted localized fields on chiral molecules will be probed through the IR and VCD spectra as the chiroptical behavior is turned on and off, as well as more finely manipulated. The studies aim to provide an understanding of how nanostructures with IR plasmonic and chiroptical activity impact molecular vibrational spectra of chiral molecules in VCD spectroscopy. The findings from these investigations will establish a foundation for plasmon-enhanced VCD for analysis of chiral molecules. Enhanced detection of chiral molecules would lower detection limits for trace impurities and could lead to highly sensitive real-time monitoring of products in asymmetric catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Chemical Measurement and Imaging award supported the research to study plasmon-enhanced Vibrational Circular Dichroism (VCD) spectroscopy for the analysis of chiral molecules which are important for the development of new therapeutics for health improvements. Chirality is a characteristic of molecules that refers to the three-dimensional organization of atoms. The chirality of molecules is of critical importance in determining molecular properties, especially in applications such as medicine where the chiral properties of drug molecules control the efficacy as well as the safety.  In the case of drug development, trace impurities in the chiral form of a molecule may be detrimental to health, but the guidelines for acceptable levels of contaminants are dependent on the availability of analytical techniques for chiral-specific detection. VCD spectroscopy can be used to assign absolute stereochemical configurations describing the three-dimensional arrangement of atoms, but the signals are small, limiting application to large quantities of material. As a result, chiral analysis of molecules is key for drug development. Because of the importance of chirality, methods to provide sensitive and specific detection of chiral moelcules are necessary.

 

The research goal was to study plasmonic nanostructures with controllable chiroptical behavior for plasmon-enhanced VCD spectroscopy for lowering detection limits. Plasmon-enhanced VCD could find utility in trace analysis of impurities and become a key analytical methodology for the pharmaceutical industry in improving both efficacy and safety of new drugs. Plasmons are the result of light interacting with metal structures with nano- to micro-sized features. At this size scale, the light causes electrons in the metal structures to oscillate in a coherent manner, producing local sculpting of electromagnetic fields. The studies focused on the interactions of chiral and achiral molecules with plasmonic materials and the introduction of these materials in the technique of VCD spectroscopy. The research provided an understanding of how nanostructures with infrared plasmonic and chiroptical activity impact molecular vibrational spectra of the molecules, including enhacing VCD signals. The findings from these investigations help establish a foundation for plasmon-enhanced-VCD  for analysis of chiral molecules. These studies laid the groundwork, but more research is needed to determine mechanisms to better understand how to implement plasmonic materials in plasmon-enhanced VCD spectroscopy. 

Research was integrated with education and training of young scientists in this project. Through the research, students gained extensive training in chemistry, optics, computational methods, materials analysis and fabrication methods. Two graduate students completed dissertations and earned Ph.D. degrees, and one senior graduate student is finishing her dissertation. Three graduate students and three undergraduate students gained extensive experience in communication of the research through presentations on campus and to broader communities at conferences and meetings. In addition to gaining new technical and problem-solving skills, the students learned to work in a collaborative manner, setting them up for team-based work in relevant areas in related industries. Students readily found employment in industry research laboratories using the skills gained from the training and experience of this research project. Students also earned recognition by fellowships and international conference presentation opportunities, including a conference award for an undergraduate research student. The research has been disseminated through one publication and two dissertations. In addition, one dissertation is in progress and multiple additional manuscripts are in the final stages of preparation for submission. The research also served as a basis for a range of activities to support science engagement with K-12 students from across the state of Utah, in addition to the educational impacts in graduate and undergraduate curriculum and the Professional Science Master’s Program at the University of Utah.
